14331.content:
Manectric awoke with a start. The last thing he remembered was a hard piece of plastic smacking his flank before he went ibto some sort of cryogenic sleep; but he had been let out again in completely different surroundings. He recognized that he was in Mauville City, but he had no idea where. Suddenly, he heard a human voice call out, "Manectric! Use Thunder Fang!" Manectric suddenly looked up, saw a Wailmer, and attacked it with a Thunder Fang.
         Another human sighed, called his Wailmer to return before a stream of red light appeared, making the Wailmer disappear into a small red ball, similar to the one Manectric had been smacked with a few minutes before. Manectric looked up at the human who had smacked him with a the ball and wagged his tail before he was congratulated with a short pat on the head. Mabectric was then put back into the cryogenic sleep that he had been put ibto before.

         When Manectric was released again, he saw a gaint manor house. Then, he heard a familiar voice call out, "Go on inside, Manectric, the master is waiting for us." Manectric had no idea what was going on--he was disoriented and unfamiliar with his surroundings. He also felt like he was being watched. No, he was not being watched, but spied upon. This was a new sensation to him that made Manectric deeply uncomfortable.
         The house was massive, with a complex grid of corridors and rooms that Manectric could immediately tell would take some time to learn to.navigate. Left, then right, then left again; then up a flight of stairs, then right again, then down a long corridor was Manectric led until the man who had caught him, before the duo reached a set of double doors that Manectric could tell was a study. The man knocked thrice before a man inside answered, "Yes, Andrew?" The man, Andrew answered, "Sir, I have the Manectric that you requested."
         Manectric heard the man inside grunt before he ostebsibly stood and opened the door. When the man opened the door, Andrew handed the other man Manectric's Poke Ball and explained whose it was before the man thanked Andrew and dismissed him before calling for Manectric into the study. But before Andrew had moved out of earshot, the man in the study called to the butler, "Gather the other Pokemon." Andrew nodded and left.
         The man called Manectric over in soothing tones before he gestured to a bowl of food. Manectric wasn't sure whether he wanted the food. Then his stomach made up his mind by grumbling rather loudly. So Manectric took a bite. The food was better than anything he had ever eaten; so Manectric took another bite; and then he took another. Soon, he had finished a bowl. The man chuckled, giving him another bowl full of food. Manectric was still unsure whether he wanted more, but he didn't feel too full; and his taste buds still wanted more. So he ate more, and he finished a second bowl. Now the man openly laughed, but Manectric wouldn't eat any more food that moment.
         Suddenly, someone, probably Andrew, knocked at the door. "Lord Gregory," called Andrew's voice, "as requested, your other Pokemon have been collected and brought here.". "Excellent, let them in. Thank you, Andrew." Andrew then opened the door and let in three other Pokemon: Mightyena, Arcanine, and Lycanroc, a diurnal one. Manectric smelled only male phermones in the room, which mildly disappointed him. The Lycanroc's face contorted slightly before he shrugged and sat quietly. The Arcanine smiled and ran up to greet Manectric, and the Mightyena rolled over excitedly and began to pant excitedly. "Good afternoon," smiled the Arcanine politely, but that was as far as Manectric got to hear before Mightyena tackled Manectric and began licking him enthusiastically and too warmly. "Mightyena," Arcanine barked, "really?" The Mightyena looked up and immediately got off Manectric.
         "I'm sorry. I just get so excited," Mightyena apologized. "I understand and forgive you," Manectric laughed after his punctual statement. Manectric walked over to Lycanroc and sniffed him. Lycanroc sat and nodded before Manectric greeted him, "Good afternoon. How are you?" The Lycanroc then spoke, "I'm fine, but quite as extroverted as those two. I'm kind of awkward around new people and Pokemon." Manectric laughed at the other Pokemon's sarcastic honesty; he liked this guy. While Manectric had been talking to Lycanroc, Mightyena had followed and intejected:
14331.title: Manectric

143311.content:
Manectric nodded, so Mightyena energetically marched ahead, explaining the various rooms. "There's Lady Sarah's, Master Gregory's spouse, bedroom. That's a bathroom; there's a storage closet, and a lounge. Let's go downstairs." Having descended the stairs, Manectric noticed a spacious foyer that led into a ballroom, according to Mightyena. "They like to host parties regularly; one will be in a few days, apparently," stated Mightyena, wandering off topic a bit, "I think that you'll have fun. I certainly did at the one I went to a couple of weeks ago. Oh, there's the kitchen." Mightyena salivated a bit before Arcanine nudged him gently, hissing, "you're drooling again, doofus." Mightyena snapped back to attention again, "Sorry, the cook is just generous to us with spoiled leftovers."
         Having finished the tour of the house, the group went out to the patio where Manectric saw a pool and an orchard with various berry plants and the like. "Do you wanna go swimming?" Mightyena asked Manectric, eagerly anticipating an affirmation. "Is the pool saltwater?" Manectric inquired in turn. "Yeah, why?" Manectric looked disappointedly at Mightyena, "do you have any idea what happens to electricity in saltwater?" When the Mightyena shook his head, Manectric continued, "Electricity gets carried through the water by the salt, meaning that anything else in the water gets zapped. And because of my static, I don't want to hurt you. Sorry."
         Mightyena pouted for a moment before he continued more sulkily, "Fine, feel free to do what you want. The other two are afraid to go swimming also. I'm going to the kitchen." Manectric thought that that plan sounded like an excellent idea, and Arcanine and Lycanroc agreed. So off they went to the kitchen.
         The chef was a rail thin, eager man, who was short with short brown hair, a shaved face, but kind, warm eyes that belied his firm exterior. When he saw Manectric, he laughed, calling one of his sous-chef to come have a look at the new addition to the house and to prepare for him a welcome dish. Manectric was at first excited before he realized that the sous-chef was merely geeting more Pokemon-food. Although he ate it happily, he was really expecting some human food. Arcanine had walked over to his food dish and began eating from it. Lycanroc had stayed back, away from the food. Mightyena called him over, inviting him to come eat. Lycanroc politely declined, saying that he was still full from breakfast.
         Mightyena then began eagerly chowing down on his food while Manectric wandered over to what the chef was making. When the chef noticed Manectric, he smiled and rubbed the Pokemon's belly with his foot when Manectric rolled over. When Mightyena had finished his bowl, he sighed and padded over to the chef, and looked with pleading, pathetic eyes that seemed almost immediately to melt the chef's heart, prompting the chef to call the sous-chef to scrounge in the refidgerator for expired leftovers.
         The sous-chef then went over and pulled out an almost full tray of party sandwiches--turkey, ham, roast beef, egg salad, and Magikarp salad sandwiches. Then he alternated giving them to Manectric and Mightyena. Then Arcanine joined the mix and Manectric left the mix, stuffed to utter capacity. Then Lycanroc joined and Arcanine left the mix. Then Manectric went back in, but Manectric noticed that Mightyena never left the sous-chef's feet. Even when the other three had had enough, Mightyena still continued to eat until all the sandwiches were gone.
         "Is he fed enough?" Manectric whispered to Lycanroc. "Yes, but he hadn't been when we found him. He was, I think, one of some Team Aqua grunt's Pokemon. They didn't feed him nearly enough. Arcanine was a Magma officer's Pokemon, so he was never fed enough either. You and I are the only ones straight from the wild. When Brendan, the Pokemon League Champion, beat Magma and Aqua, those two were released; and Master Gregory adopted them. I was his first Pokemon. I've known him for a few months now, but the other two only have been here for a few weeks. They've made good progress on regaining deficient body mass. Lycanroc sat down, his glistening light-brown fur sat nearly perfectly on his back. But Manectric noticed a small fold of what appeared to be skin forming above Lycanroc's stomach when he sat. He had noticed something similar in Mightyena and Lycanroc. It really wasn't a big deal, but it was noticeable.
         Having decided that he wanted a nap, everyone plodded heavily outside and lay down on the concrete for a nap. Manectric did the same; but while everyone else was in a food-induced comatose state, he decided that he needed to go around the house to check out more of it. His stomach sloshed around, and the midday sun on top of it didn't feel too pleasant. It was the middle of summer and quite hot, so Manectric began to pant, so he went inside, where he found…
143311.title: "Want to go explore the house?"

choices: More preparation details for the party.
1433112.content:
"Ah, Manectric," called Andrew, "just what I was looking for. Where are the others? We need to round them up for super training." So Manectric led Andrew to the others, who all, especially Mightyena, grimaced when Andrew declared what he intended for them to do.
         "So, what is this 'super training'?" Manectric turned to Mightyena. "Super training involves the use of these stupid toys designed to improve certain battle staistics for us. It's a form of EV training. It's grueling and difficult, and I'm terrible at it all. None of us is good, but I'm the worst." Manectric nodded, understanding Mightyena's frustration at his own failure. Manectric could also hear the food still sloshing around in Mightyena's stomach, which would make Mightyena uncomfortable at best.
         The group arrived at the training room of the house. It was a spacious room, only a bit smaller than the kitchen, with dumbells, treadmills, and various balls of all sizes and shapes. In the corner was a punching bag and some targets for practice. Manectric was still surveying the room when Andrew suddenly called, "Ok, who wants to go first?" When no one came forward, Andrew eventually called out, "Come on, you lazy bums, let's go." Eventually, because he felt likw he had betrayed his group, Manectric decided to go first. "Good, we have a volunteer. Let's do some Attack training first."
         Andrew then told Maectric to try and hit the bag as hard as he could. So Manectric did, repeatedly, until Andrew called time. The punching bag must have had an instrument inside it to measure force with which it had been hit, because Andrew called out, "56.3 Newtons per square meter, slightly below average for a Manectric of your age and level. Don't worry, we'll get you there." Manectric nodded, feeling his stomach pulsing. He now felt nauseated mildly, but he staggered over to his peers and flopped down.
         "Exhausting, huh," Mightyena whispered gloomily. Manectric could only nod his head in agreement. Lycanroc went next, and he pleased Andrew with an apparent marked improvement over the previous week. Then Arcanine went, after whose attempt, Andrew's face appeared ambivalent. No serious change in Attack was noticed. But Lycanroc was a physical attacker, and Arcanine was not; so these results were not terribly surprising. Then up lumbered Mightyena sluggishly.
         Mightyena tried to jump before he barely managed to hit the bag. And after that sorry attempt, Mightyena looked visibly shaken. He tried again. This time, he managed to land a more convincing hit on the bag. And for half the time, he managed to buildon each successive attempt, successfully hitting the bag harder each time. But such efforts visibly drained Mightyena, who didn't appear to have the stamina to carry on. After his sixth attempt, Mightyena fell clumsily on his right hind leg. He tried to stand, but his leg wobbled too much to be of much use; so he collapsed again, completely this time, utterly defeated.
         Although his hits had been decent, Mightyena's stamina thoroughly disappointed Andrew. "Allright, your laziness, let's see you do defense training first." Defense training was effectively just holding dumbells above one's head for as long as one could. Mightyena managed to do fine on this one, but again disppointed Andrew, "Come on, any average fighting type could beat you in two hits, and the best at you level could in one."
         To Manectric, Mightyena looked ready either to cry or vomit, Manectric couldn't tell. "It's ok," Manectric reassured Manectric, "You're being held to a high standard on a full stomach. I'm sure you're better than these scores indicate." Mightyena nodded but appeared to take little solace from Manectric's words.
         But in Special Attack training, a mix of accuracy and power, Mightyena scored well above average for his breed and level, a boone given that Shadow Ball and Dark Pulse were his two favorite moves, and the ones that Gregory most often used. Special Defense training, which consisted mostly of dodging rubber balls, Mightyena was about average when everyone else was below average. Then came the Speed trainig.
         It was just a treadmill that Andrew gradually accelerated, but Mightyena hated the thought of running on a full stomach. He asked everyone to go before he went, and all obliged him. Things went off without a hitch for the first three. Speed was mildly above average for all the other three. When Manectric jumped off the treadmill, he laughed with Mightyena and chuckled, "Come on, you big lug, it's your turn." Mightyena nodded nervously, obviously not wanting to be ridiculed by Andrew or to lose his afternoon meal.
         Things started off well for Mightyena, seamelessly transitioning from a walk to a jog to a run. But everyone could hear Mightyena panting by the time Mightyena was breaking into a sprint. He looked green with nausea. And in his nausea, he began to totter until he tripped. He tripped and was flung into the wall on his back. There was a crater where Mightyena had hit the wall and a tremendous thump had followed. Andrew rushed over and check for broken bones. Fortuneately he found none.
         Upstairs, Gregory heard a muffled thump below him. In the gym? He decided to go inspect it.
         Andrew managed to help a dazed and stunned Mightyena up to his feet, but not before he heard the heavy, deliberate steps of his employer. "What the hell is…my Arceus…Andrew, what did you do?". After the butler had explained what had happened, Gregory stood up, his young, bearded, and stout face stern with resolve. "No more of that, Andrew. For any of them." "But, sir," Andrew equivocated, "what will we do for their Speed EV's? It's far too hot for them outside, and not all of them can use the pool." Gregory stared patronizingly at his butler, "Andrew, don't tell me you can't think of some other exercise for them." Andrew nodded, but honestly couldn't, not for a gym anyway.
         Gregory fumed out of the gym and up the stairs. Over the next few days, Lycanroc broke four punching bags, Manectric dropped dumbells on his chest five times, and Arcanine and made the plaster of the wall scorched from missing the targets with his Flamethrower attack. The first time, all these things had happened by accident, but the next few times, they were deliberate; so Gregory decided, against Andrew's advice, to stop the EV training. That decision suited everyone, especially Mightyena, just fine.

         Preparations for the party the next day were well under way. Food was beginning to be ordered to prepare, decorations were set up, the house was made immaculate, and none of the Pokemon were allowed to go outside together. They weren't even allowed to go out alone with a leash and a human escort because they had been groomed, and Lady Sarah didn't want to ruin that. Manectric liked the glossy sheen and the soft feel of his coat after he had been groomed, as opposed to the shaggy mass of fur he was used to. The party was coming.
1433112.title: Andrew

14331122.content:
Last minute preparations were being made, but everything was practically ready for the party. Everyone seemed absent-minded, rushing to and fro to get things done. The Pokemon were given a steady stream of sample food throughout the day from the chef. And the Pokemon food flowed more freely than it ever had before. Everyone took advantage of that, especially Arcanine and Mightyena. But that flow of food died down by two in the afternoon.
         Everything was ready by seven o'clock, an hour before the guests were set to arrive, because Gregory anticipated that some guests would come early--some always did. Sure enough, at 7:45, the first guests arrived. They were obviously from Gregory's parents' generation, and Manectric found out that the two were indeed his parents. They were built like their son, and Manectric could trace most of his master's features from them. The man was heavyset like his son, perhaps more so; but his wife was thin and elegant for her age, with sharp eyes and an aquiline nose like her son; and Manectric learned that his smarts had come from her. But his father was the sweetest, most compassionate man Manectric had ever met. He pet all his son's Pokemon until the other guests arrived, doling out treats as he went. Mightyena explained that this had happened the last time too.
         Gregory's father, Dave, grunted and wheezed as he stood, laughing that he was too old to be bending down like that. His wife silently rolled her eyes, saying that she could have bent down like Dave had just fine. It was because he was fat that he couldn't do it. Dave merely laughed and shrugged, "That could be too. I don't know, dear." As guests strolled in and the foyer filled up, Gregory suggested that the party move to the hors d'oeuvres table in the dining room. Manectric had no idea what an "hors d'oeuvre" was, but it sounded promising. Lycanroc saw the confused expression on Manectric's face and whispered: "'Hors d'oeuvre' is Kalosian for 'food away from the table.' It's just a fancy way of saying 'food before a meal.'"
         Lycanroc turned out to be right. Gregory's announcement meant food. "Ok," Mightyena whispered to Manectric, "spread out, and don't beg too often. That's how Lycanroc has said that he's gotten the most food from people. It worked pretty well for me. So I'll go over there, Lycnanroc and Arcanine have already chosen corners. Let's split up." Manectric agreed and went his way from Mightyena. Manectric was careful to note who he had begged food from, who had been watching him, and how frequently he begged from people. Food seemed to flow in a steady stream as if people were expected to feed the animals. Some people evwn sought Manectric out to dump food on him.
         Eventually, Gregory called for everyone to move to the main table to eat. In the same manner as with the hors d'oeuvres, the four Pokemon each took a side of the square table and began to beg from it. People were just as generous, if not more generous with their dinners after they had filled up with hors d'oeuvres than they were with the hors d'oeuvres. Manectric even saw Mightyena get whole plates of food for himself. By the time everyone had finished eating, three of the four Pokemon, the exception being Mightyena, met at the middle of the table, under the table.
         "I can't eat any more," huffed Manectric. "I could still go for desert," sighed Arcanine. "Yeah, but you outweigh us two to one. So no wonder." Lycanroc laughed. Mightyena was still begging for food, despite that there was a slight distension to his stomach from all the food he had eaten. "Man, Mightyena sure likes to eat," Lycanroc chuckled, "but how can anyone blame him. He was starved by those Aqua bastards, after all."
         After desert, Mightyena slowly plodded over to the others and lay down gingerly, ready to pass out. He had been asleep for a few minutes when everyone heard Gregory's voice call out, "Is anyone ready for some battles?" He got some hearty laughs and a few words of support for his motion. "Well, it's decided then. There are…32 of us. Perfect! That's just enough for a perfect single elimination tournament! Let's draw numbers to see who battles who first. 1 against 32, 2 against 31, et cetera. So let's draw numbers out of a hat then, shall we?" "I don't know for whom you're stalling!" Everyone laughed.
         When everyone had a number, Gregory's was 29. That meant, according to Arcanine, who knew that Gregory owned four battle-pitches; so Gregory would be one of the first eight up. "Someone needs to wake him," Arcanine joked, gesturing to Mightyena, who was out-cold. "It's fine. It's three on three; so if he wants to sleep, let him," countered Lycanroc. Arcanine shrugged. Forcing his exhausted body up and over to his master. The trio found Gregory, who looked befuddled. "Where's Mightyena?" he asked hurriedly. The trio of Pokemon turned when Gregory smiled and beamed, "There you are! I'll need you. Lycanroc, you can sit this one out. I'll need you next time, so you should rest. Come on guys, return." Thus began the short cryogenic sleep.
14331122.title: Skip to the party.

143311221.content:
Lycanroc watched as Gregory prepared for battle and waited for his opponent to select three Pokemon. "Ok, gentlemen, select your first Pokemon." Then, louder so that everyone could hear him: "Ladies and gentlemen, I now present to you the Pokemon Battle between Duke Gregory and Viscountess Jeanette. And begin!"
         The Lady, Jeanette, called her Pokemon first, "I choose you, Gyarados!" Gregory scoffed, "You're so predictable. Go, Manectric!" Manectric stood, staring at a twenty-foot tall monster, an intimidating one, to say the least while he had a full stomach that churned when it saw the Gyarados. "Gyrados, Dragon Rage!" shouted Jeanette. "Manectric, dodge and use Thunderbolt." countered Gregory. Manectric didn't manage to evade the attack, launched from close range at a full and petrified target; but he did managw to launch the best Thunderbolt he had. The Gyarados contorted with rage and pain before it fell over, unconscious.
         "Gyarados is unable to battle. The winner is Gregory. Lady Viscountess, state your next Pokemon," declared the referee. The viscountess was too stunned to answer for a moment before she stammered, "Ah, hm, I think it'll be Gardevoir." The referee nodded, "will you switch your Pokemon, sir?" Gregory considered for a moment, "No, sir, I will not. I have full confidence in my Manectric." Manectric beamed with pride. "Very well, then. Begin!"
         "Gardevoir, I need you now tonight!" Jeanette pleaded. "Manectric, Thunderbolt!" Gregory shouted quickly. Manectric then let out another Thunderbolt. "Gardevoir, Psychic!" Jeanette barked, regaining her composure. The attack hit Manectric like a brick wall of energy, sapping him of all power. But he didn't faint. "Manectric, one more time!" "Gardevoir, Calm Mind!"
         Manectric was astounded when the Gardevoir didn't faint. "Draining Kiss!" shouted the Viscountess. The damned Gardevoir was on top of Gardevoir before everything went black.

         Lycanroc watched as Manectric was sapped of all his strength and as the Gardevoir regained some of its own (Lycanroc had to refer to the Gardevoir that way because it was androgenous, not because he deemed it an inferior life form). "Lord Gregory, what Pokemon will you send out next?" inquired the referee. "Mightyena," stated Gregory in reply. "Lady Jeanette, will you change Pokemon?" When the Viscountess shook her head, the referee began the match again.
         "Mightyena, Shadow Ball!" ordered Gregory. Mightyena obeyed immediately, landing a direct hit; but he caused little damage. "Gardevoir, Draining Kiss," the Viscountess sneered, demanding her Pokemon obey. "Mightyena, dodge," screamed Gregory in panick, knowing that Draining Kiss was very effective against Mightyena. But Mightyena, still full from the banquet beforehand, responded poorly and sluggishly; so he got a direct hit scored on him. But he didn't faint.
         "Allright, Mightyena, way to hang in there!" Gregory cheered, trying to encourage his weary partner. "Do you really think he can survive another Draining Kiss?" Jeanette laughed, deriding Gregory's optimism, "Gardevoir, Draining Kiss." Gregory didn't utter a command.
         Gardevoir was closing, but Gregory still said nothing. Then, just before Gardevoir reached Mightyena, he yelled, "Shadow Ball, Mightyena!" Mightyena instantly obeyed, just in time to smack Gardevoir with it before it could get out of the way, and knocking it flat on its back. "Now, again, Shadow Ball!" Mightyena again obeyed instantly. Gardevoir did not get up afterward, having been knocked out. "Winner!" shouted the referee; and Mightyena collapsed, unable to continue.
         "Uh," stared the referee, "Mightyena is unable to continue. Each party will now cast out their third and final Pokemon!" Lycanroc was amazed. Mightyena had never showed that kind of endurance before that battle. To do so now was amazing for one so uninterested in battle. "Go, Arcanine," cried Gregory with sheer glee. "Go, Lucario!" smiled Jeanette, in a seeming concession of defeat. "And begin."
         "Arcanine, Flamethrower," commanded Gergory. "Lucario, dig," whispered Jeanette. "Damn it," fumed Gregory. Jeanette laughed jovially, "My dear Duke, did you think honestly that I would let you off so easily? You're not a damned fool. But neither am I. Now Lucario." Gregory panicked, "Arcanine, beneath you, now, Flamethrower!" Arcanine's speed of reflexes surprised Jeanette, especially because of Gregory's uncomposed flailing. Arcanine hit Lucario just as he was coming up; and the two collide in a meaty thud that sounded quite painful to all who heard it. Both Pokemon dropped to the ground in a heap, not moving. "Because neither Pokemon is able--" he stopped suddenly; and Jeanette and Gregory watched as Arcanine struggled to his feet when Lucario did not. "Lucario is unable to continue; therefore, the victroy and the game go to Arcanine and Duke Gregory!"
         The small crowd that had gathered to watch the only match still going on erupted in cheers and applause, before they quickly went back to soing what they had been doing before, including Grand Duke Dave.
         The rest of the matches went off without much serious competition, so Gregory was worried about the calibre of his opponents for the fights to come.
143311221.title: The first battle.

1433112211.content:
Gregory had no idea why he had been worried abou the calibre of his opponents. His second match had been a clean sweep with Lycanroc, Manectric, and Mightyena steamrolling opponents. Gregory had comforted the poor man he had beaten the beatdown had been so one-sided. With his match having ended, Gregory looked around and saw his father preparing for his next battle. His father's Salamence had cruised through the first battle with barely a scratch. But his second opponent wouldn't be a pushover, Gregory knew.
         Dave's next opponent would be Baron Eddie, a man about Gregory's age. Eddie had chosen as his Pokemon Torkoal, Magneton, and Quagsire, a match if Gregory's father had ever seen one. Gregory was about to offer his father some encouragement when a referee walked up and told Dave that his match was about to start.
         Gregory hurried over to his father's match and managed to catch it from the beginning. "Grand Duke Dave, choose your first Pokemon. Now you, Baron Eddie." When each had chosen his Pokemon, the referee whistled; and both threw out their Pokemon.
         Gregory looked at his father's Salamence more closely now that he could get more than fleeting glances of it. Gregory knew immediately that something seemed off. He knew Salamence was a naturally blocky Pokemon in its physique, but Dave's Salamence's stomach barely cleared the ground when it stood. It also seemed to have a bit of trouble getting to its feet. But with one Dragon Pulse, Eddie's Quagsire had fainted. The other two Pokemon of the Baron's faced similar fates equally quickly.
         After the battle, Gregory went up to congratulate his father, "Dad, Salamence was great as usual, even though he seemed exhausted by the end of it, though he barely suffered any damage." Dave looked concerned, "He seemed fine to me. Why?" Gregory smiled, "Dad, your Salamence looks like he needs a bit more training time. He seems to be going a bit soft." Dave laughed, "Your mother says the same thing, and that he should be as heavy as he is. I always tell her that they never feed the Salamences that they put in the Pokedex enough. Salamences are supposed to be blockier than the Pokedex's deceptive entry would lead you to believe. The space between his belly and the floor should be minimal when he stands. Besides, Salamence had no trouble flying the last time we went flying."
         "Four months ago," chimed in Gregory's mother. "Dave, admit it; your Salamence is fat and needs to lose weight, just like you." Dave went red in the face, "The jokes about me I can take, but I would appreciate if you didn't insult my Pokemon, Nancy." Nancy was taken aback at her husband's inclemency. She was trying to be gentle, but gentility was not her strong suit. "I'm sorry, dear. I won't offend you like that again. I didn't mean to affront you." Dave nodded, "I'm sorry I snapped at you dear. I shouldn't have. Forgive me."
         Dave rolled his eyes at the mushy sentimentalism that his parents loved to share with each other, but he endured it with a silent chuckle. The third round should have been about to begin, thought Gregoty, and told his father so. The third round went well for Gregory, with Arcanine, Lycanroc, and Manectric battling, and only Arcanine fainting. In the third round, however, Dave decided to use his Zebstrika. It was a beautiful creature, with a barrell-shaped chest, with sleek skin, and ribs covered in a svelte layer of fat completely, so much so that the Pokemon's back made a crease in the middle. It stood stolidly and destroyed each of its opponent's Pokemon. The fourth round passed without much fanfare either, with Mightyena, Arcanine, and Lycanroc all beating their opponents. And Dave's Salamence beat all of its opponents lying down. Nancy whispered in her son's ear that Salamence was lying down because it was too tired to stand. The crowd loved the Salamence nevertheless.
         Before the final round between father and son, everyone went to go get desert and refreshments. Dave even let his three Pokemon out of their Pokeballs.
1433112211.title: The Second Match.

14331122111.content:
After Dave had brought out a piece of cake and a bowl of ice cream for his three Pokemon and his son's four and had left, the seven Pokemon began to mingle. Salamence and Zebstrika were both outgoing and friendly, if calm and laid back. But Dave's third Pokemon, Swampert, was more aloof and standoffish. He barely said anything, but he at least listened intently to what everyone else was saying eventually. Lycanroc didn't appear to know Swampert, either, so it was clear that Swampert was a new addition.
         Manectric was also surprised how heavy Dave's Pokemon were. He had seen a Salamence once; and although he knew that they weren't slender to begin with, the one Manectric had seen had been able to lift his belly off the ground more than the couple inches Dave's Salamence could. Perhaps that was just a result of domestication, Manectric thought, because all Dave's Pokemon seemed to be more massive, especially at the waist, than any Manectric had seen in the wild; but he didn't bring up the issue.
         Manectric glanced at Mightyena, who looked like he had put on a few pounds just in the past several days Manectric had known him. Manectric then looked at himself. He knew the shape of his torso before he had been captured, and he saw that the very pronounced hourglass at his waist had grown less pronounced since he had arrived. That was just the result of being fed properly, Manectric reasoned.
         These things weren't pressing issues in Manectric's mind, but they were amusing. Manectric then looked at Swampert's torso. The usually thin form Manectric was used to with Swamperts was not there, usurped by a pendulous mass that hung to just a couple of inches above Swampert's knees. It was mildly adorable, Manectric mused to himself contentedly. Dave then returned and snuck everyone a second round of dessert while he ate his own. Manectric saw why Dave's Pokemon adored their master.
         Soon after Dave had thrown away the trash from the paper plates, while he stroked his Salamence's generous underside, eliciting a contented purr from the dragon, the referee came up and told Dave that his final battle was about to begin. Dave nodded, returned his Pokemon, and called his son over before he told his son the news he had just been given. Gregory nodded and called back his Pokemon to himself. He took Lycanroc, Mightyena, and Manectric, allowing Arcanine to sit and rest, digesting the desert it had just devoured.
         "Gentlemen, select your first Pokemon," called the referee. "Now, ladies and gentlemen, I announce to you the battle between Grand Duke David and Duke Gregory; let the battle begin!" Gregory then summoned his first Pokemon, "Lycanroc, I choose you!" Dave smiled, amused that he had become so predictable, "Salamence, you're up." "GO!" shouted the referee, and the match began.
         "Lycanroc, Rock Slide," ordered the Duke. "Salamence, Fly!" countered the Grand Duke; but Salamence didn't. It tried, but its weight bogged it down, so it was too slow. Consequently, it got slammed with a mass of rock. "Ok, Salamence, Iron Tail!" Salamence then tried to run up, but once again, its bulk slowed it down to such a degree that Gregory could counter, "Lycanroc, Rock Tomb," and hit Salamence dead-on, knocking Salamence out. "Salamence is unable to continue, Lycanroc wins!"
         Everyone stood shocked in a dazed silence at what had just happened. The immortal Salamence had just fallen to a Lycanroc, one single Lycanroc. "Sir, pick your next Pokemon," urged the referee, galvanizing Dave from his stupor. "R-right," he muttered, "Swanpert, I choose you." There sat Swampert, with Gregory looking perplexed, "Ok, Lycanroc, return. Go, Mightyena!" "Allright, then. Battle, continue!"
         "Swampert, Earthquake!" barked Dave, breaking from his usually serene demeanor. Swampert immediately obeyed, not jumping to its feet, but coming close, it sat and used the move in the laziest way possible, "Mightyena, Dark Pulse," countered Gregory, as soon as the Earthquake had stopped. "Swampert, Waterfall," demanded Gregory, more calmly, but no less intensely. Swampert then slowly rose to its feet, but moved afterward with amazing speed for such a bulky Pokemon, smacking Migthyena, causing Mightyena to flinch. "Again, Surf!" laughed Dave, in a cold laugh that Gregory had only ever heard his mother use, at least among his parents. After the wave had passed, Mightyena lay knocked out on the ground. "Mightyena is unable to continue. Swmapert wins!" proclaimed the referee.
         Everyone cheered again. Gregory was now white with fear. He now had nothing against which Swampert didn't have a very-effective type-advantage in Swampert. "Ah, go, Manectric," he called timidly, with a wobble in his voice. "And, continue," the referee announced. "Swampert, use Earthquake," and, again, from a reclining position, Swampert launched his attack. With devastating effectiveness, Swampert, in one move, pulverized Manectric, knocking it out like a light.
         "'Manectric is unable to continue, Swampert wins!" cried the referee. Gregory saw the futile hope of this, but he ordered out Lycanroc anyway, which was swept away by one Surf attack. Gregory laughed and conceded defeat, "Dad, you're as good as ever; and Swampert is amazing!" Dave blushed, "Well, that's why I had Professor Birch send me that Mudkip a few months ago, to beat you. "It's so regal," Gregory added, "I mean, it didn't even have to stand to beat Manectric or Lycanroc. But is Salamence ok? I mean, he used to be able to dodge Lycanroc's Rock Slide with no problem. What happened?" Dave smiled wearily, checking to make sure his wife wasn't lurking, as she was wont to do, "Contrary to what your mother says, he's just getting old, like me, I'm afraid. He also doesn't fly me nearly as many places as he used to. So it's, I think, just a combination of age and lack of recent practice." Gregory nodded, not seeing anything wrong with hsi father's assessment.
         "And Swampert, ever since he evolved from being a Marshtomp has been averse to exercise, which is fine given that I want a docile inside pet. But we still have to make sure he doesn't jump in the pool--he's been known to muddy it up." Gregory laughed at his father's half-joking attitude. Nancy then approached, "Dave, we ought to be getting home soon. It's late, and we have a long day tomorrow. Did you make the arrangements for the Pokemon?"
         Dave looked sheepishly at his wife, "No, I'm afraid not. But I was getting there. Gregory, we'll be out of town for a couple of weeks on a cruise to the battle frontier's beach resort; and unfortuneately, I can't take my Pokemon with me, could you look after them for a couple of days while we get to the Battle Frontier?" Gregory…
14331122111.title: The Fifth Battle.

143311221111.content:
"Sure, Dad, let me run that plan by Sarah first, before I give you confirmation," he turned, saw his wife standing next to him. She nodded politely, with what Gregory could tell was a forced grin. Gregory gave her a glance before he asked, "Mom, Dad, could we have a word for a moment?" Dave and Nancy nodded, aware of their son's predicament then. "Is everything ok, Sarah?" Sarah nodded but replied, "Gregory, these Pokemon your father has are not small. Where will we put them? We already have four Pokemon as it is!" Gregory nodded, "But it'll just be for a few days. I'm sure that we can make the best arrangements. Dad will, I'm sure, bring their food. And we can give them a couple of guest bedrooms to them, it's not like we haven't quite a few."
         Sarah finally conceded in disgust. "Come on, dear. It'll be just us for a while afterward. You know how much I like to be around other people," Gregory pleaded. "Fine, go ahead; but they'd better not cause trouble," Sarah warned. When Gregory relayed the news to his parents, they sighed in relief, "Ok, we'll take them home tonight; but thanks so much for this!" Dave gushed. And with that, Gregory's parents left.

         At 8:30 the next morning, Andrew heard a knock at the door, "Coming," he called as he unlocked the door to see Dave and Nancy at the door. "Ah," Andrew grunted, recalling what Gregory had told him last night about his parents, "You can leave the Pokemon with me. I'll be sure to take good care of them." Nancy looked rebuffed at the butler's bad manners before Dave gestured that they had to go, they had a taxi waiting. "Right," Nancy remembered as she walked down the steps to the car. "Tell my son thanks!" Dave called as he was leaving. Andrew nodded and went inside.
         "Who was that at the door?" inquired Gregory. "Your parents, sir, to drop off your father's Pokemon," Andrew replied flatly. "Well, let them out!" bubbled Gregory like a small child getting a present or his first Pokemon. Andrew rolled his eyes amusedly, but did as he was told. Dave's Pokemon all emerged from their Poke Balls looking rather sleepy from last night's festivities. Mightyena popped his head in through the doorway to see the commotion and saw Salamence, Zebstrika, and Swampert, who were all crowded around Gregory's feet begging for food and getting none. "I see that Dad's up to his usual tricks," Gregory chuckled playfully, "feeding you all table scraps. Well, since you're not my Pokemon, whatever." And he proceeded to shovel the leftover's of his breakfast evenly into the three Pokemon's mouths.
         Mightyena was immediately jealous, and he felt stupid because he had never thought to ask Gregory for food because he felt guilty doing so. But once Gregory finished, the other three Pokemon stood and walked away. Only Salamence noticed Mightyena as he struggled to hoist his behemoth stomach off the floor. Doing that took a few moments of shimmying and scrambling before Salamence was successful. "Ah, Mightyena," he called, greeting the Dark-type, "before you ask, yes, I'm fine. I'm just getting old, according to my master. Lord, my knees hurt." Salamence oscillated his stomach from side to side as he walked, keeping his stomach two or three inches above the ground at all times. "Shall we go get breakfast?" Salamence asked Mightyena, who was taken aback by the request, because Salamence had presumably just eaten.
         "Ah, sure, sir," Mightyena sputtered nervously, "if you aren't full. I wouldn't want to bore you with my eating or tantalize you with something you couldn't have." "Nonsense," cried Salamence, "I'm famished, and Lord Gregory's treat was delightful, but only an hors d'oeuvre for me. I'm also quite sure that my master has brought my food over here."
         And indeed he had, a whole giant bag of it, enough to last even Salamence a week. The others had joined Mightyena and Salamence when they heard the bowls of food being prepared--the first two were on seconds each, and Salamence almost to thirds. Everyone ate at least one bowl of breakfast that morning, but only Lycanroc ate one, but he said that he would be back later for more. And he waited in the back while Salamence and Mightyena finished their fourth bowls of breakfast each. After he had eaten, Salamence plopped down where he was for a nap in Gregory's office, breathing silently but deeply. Mightyena thought Salamence had the right idea and joined the dragon.
         The daily routine for Manectric was simple: get up, go outside to relieve himself, eat breakfast, explore, nap, and watch Gregory read and shuffle papers. But today was different because Gregory was out of town on a business trip to Lilycove City to check on how Captain Stern's ferry, of which Gregory was a chief shareholder, was operating. Manectric watched Mightyena and Salamence breath deeply and quietly on the rug, digesting breakfast. Lycanroc and Arcanine were talking and digesting breakfast with Swampert and Zebstrika.
         Things were going pretty well, but they were also quite boring. Manectric decided to go downstairs with the other four. That was until…
143311221111.title: Nodded

choices: Enter the grind of daily life.
1433112211111.content:
Manectric had been meditating by himself for a while when he heard the heavy footsteps of Mightyena approaching. "Manectric, Manectric," Mightyena huffed excitedly, laughing, "Come see, Salamence can't get off the floor. It's the funniest thing!" Manectric stared, being dragged along practically by Mighyena. 'The poor dragon," was all Manectric could think, stultified and speechless by Mightyena's announcement. Manectric arrived at the study to find that, to his horror, Salamence was indeed not able to lift his undercarriage off the ground.
         Salamence was rightfully blubbering in a state of sheer terror at being unable to move without scraping himself on the hard floors. "Give it some time," Manectric suggested timidly, "I'm sure you're just full and need some time digesting. You'll be fine, I'm sure. You just ate too much in one sitting, that's all." Salamence snapped his head around, gazing in sheer terror that someone else had seen him in so compromised a state, "Please," Salamence begged with tears streaming down his cheeks, "I supplicate before you to ask that you not tell a single soul of this encounter today. Do you hear? No one!"
         Manectric nodded, and Salamence calmed considerably, "Sleep it off," whispered Manectric reassuringly, "you'll be fine." Salamence nodded, pacified by Manectric's advice. Salamence then proceeded to drift off to sleep.
         Manectric turned to Mightyena, and the two finished off the food in their bowls before they went outside to talk with the others. Manectric, walking behind the energetic Mightyena, could not help notice, however, that the Dark type of the house's abdomen swung from side to side with each step Mightyena took, and that any hourglass figure that Mightyena had once had was now gone. Mightyena also appeared to have a rock of food in his stomach from breakfast.
         When the two arrived, Mightyena was panting from the short walk. "I ate too much at breakfast," he murmured to himself giddily. "Where's Salamence?" asked Zebstrika, with a flash of worry crossing his face before Manectric smoothly replied, "Oh, he's taking a nap. He says that he needs some time to digest his food." Zebstrika nodded, having the worry evaporate from his face, "Ok, man, Swampert, he does seem to do that often." Swampert nodded, "Yeah, I wonder whether he's doing ok sometimes."
         Zebstrika nodded, closing the conversation on the matter. "I'm starting to get hungry again," muttered Zebstrika, despite that he had had a breakfast little more than an hour before. Manectric chuckled and determined that was the cause of the absence of ribs Manectric was used to seeing on Zebstrika. "We just had breakfast an hour ago, though," laughed Manectric, voicing his own thoughts. Zebstrika heaved what he could of his torso between his legs and forced himself up with a small grunt, "As Lord Dave says, there's no such thing as wasted food so long as it gets eaten. He also says that it's always better to have an excess than a shortage." Everyone laughed at that nugget of wisdom, but Manectric still chided, "But seriously, Salamence was asleep in there last time I checked. Is there perhaps anything else you'd like to do?" Zebstrika chortled before he stated, "With these old bones? Are you joking? No, I'm afraid that I'm not as athletic or as into athleticism as when I was young, and I'm growing a bit tired of talking right now. You all are great company, but I do like some time to myself once in a while."
         Manectric shook his head and laughed with amusement, "Maybe we can get the chef to give us some of the party's leftovers." Zebstrika's and Swampert's ears perked at that, "Leftovers? Show us!" Swampert huffed, "Why have you been withholding them?"
         Mighyrna laughed, "Because we're greedy and selfish bastards." Zebstrika snorted in mockery at Mightyena's failed sarcasm, causing Mightyena to go quiet in shame. "No, but seriously," Manectric laughed awkwardly, "Mightyena was just being sarcastic. We honestly didn't think to ask. We usually wait until after Mr. Gregory has had his midday meal. But I'm sure we can ask the chef for some sort of leftovers." Zebstrika nodded with enthusiasm, "If we're going to do this, Salamence would be offended if we didn't ask him to tag along. Someone should go wake him." Mightyena looked at Manectric quickly, "Oh, Salamence told us that he didn't want to be disturbed, and that he would come down when he was ready," Manectric covered, scrambling for an explanation.
         "And now I'm good and ready," came a deep, sonorous voice behind them all. Everyone watched as Salamence landed gracefully, if heavily, on his feet in the middle of the circle everyone had made. Salamence grunted and pushed his undercarriage off the ground, but leaving it dangerously close. "Shall we be off then? I'm ready to go get these leftovers!" exclaimed the dragon, seeming to salivate at the thought. "That settles that then," proclaimed Arcanine with glee. The group then rose and mozied comfortably to the kitchen area, where the chef, whose name, Manectric had discovered, was Gus.
         "Well, look at my favorite little Pokemon," the wiry man cooed in a demeaning fashion fit only for newborn Pokemon. The four hosts then walked away and allowed the three guests to cleave some bits and morsels for themselves, especially because they had a knack for it. Gus initially managed to hold out before he gave in and fed the three Pokemon. In prudence, however, Salamence wandered away the fastest, allowing Mightyena to get a chance at some leftovers. Quickly, however, the font of leftovers, because of the newness and freshness of said leftovers, dried up, meaning that no one but the three guests, Mightyena, and Arcanine got any. Lycanroc didn't seem too devastated, but Manectric was a bit annoyed. But he didn't allow his irritation to show, knowing that more would come his way once the guests had gone.
         But not feeling full, however, Zebstrika decided to go to his normal food bowl upstairs and to gorge himself from it. Swampert joined him, as did Mightyena and Arcanine. Lycanroc even drained another bowl, a rarity for Lycanroc. But Manectric decided to wait until everyone was lying on the floor napping to finish his bowl and another. Salamence was the only one who didn't eat more, a fact of which Manectric was proud.
         The next couple of days passed, and Salamence managed to control his diet for that time, but no one else did. Zebstrika and Swampert each seemed to gain about five pounds between their arrival and departure times. Even Mightyena and Arcanine were not immune to these trends, putting on a solid three and seven pounds respectively.
         Even Manectric and Lycanroc noticed subtle changes in their own and each other's figures. Their shape was becoming more tubular, more rounded generally. It was a trend of which they neither felt giddiness, like the others, nor contempt and hatred, like Nancy. It was pure ambivalence, so long as they could run around and explore, they were fine.
1433112211111.title: Mightyena ran up to him.

14331122111112.content:
Each day seemed rather similar and boring to Manectric after a while. The grounds were pretty, but very static, even to the point of seeming to Manectric to be stagnant. Manectric had learned all of the paths and rooms by heart by then and found them so boring from day to day. Gregory never took him or any of the other Pokemon anywhere, few people visited, and when they did, they seldom had any Pokemon and never wanted to let them out to play. So that reduced Manectric and the other Pokemon to the three things that were always changing: food, themselves, and their thoughts.
         That meant in practice that all they seemed to do was eat, sleep, perform necessary maintenance, and talk. Their one source of positive human attention was Gus, who loved them, played with them, gave them treats from his cupboard, and stroked them in turn. Responsibilities for feeding the Pokemon were also delegated to him by Andrew, who had lost all interest in training the Pokemon. Consequently, over time, the Pokemon, especially when Gregory was away, spent more and more time with Gus. Mightyena especially did this, and Arcanine usually joined him while Lycanroc and Mnectric went outside to play and even battle each other once in a while.
         "We need to leave," whispered Lycanroc to Manectric. Manectric did a double take, "What? Lycanroc, don't joke about things like that." Lycanroc shook his head, "No, I wasn't joking. We need to leave. Look at what this life is doing to us. My torso looks like a sausage, yours is no better, and look at Mightyena's the next time you get the chance--or Arcanine's! They're massive globs of fat!" Manectric was appalled, "Lycanroc, sure they're a bit heavy, but--"
         He got no further when Lycanroc growled, "A little heavy? Manectric, are you blind? We are 'a little heavy.' Their bodies shake with each step they take. The other two get winded from even the smallest physical exertion. Look at them. My mother, may she rest in peace, always said that an adult's body should always have its waist significantly narrower than either its shoulders or haunches without having ribs showing. Look especially at Mightyena. When he sits, maybe not yet when he stands, but he's awfully close, his waist is wider than his shoulders and his haunches, even when he hasn't gorged himself for a while, look when he gets up in the morning, for example. And when he has just stuffed his face silly, it's even worse. And Arcanine is only a step behind Mightyena."
         Lycanroc stood easily, and Manectric mirrored him. They both stood far more easily than the other two did, who had to rock their weight onto the ground beneath their legs--at least, what they could with the rest spilling over their legs--and rock themselves and heave themselves up off the ground in a slow, laborious process. Manectric knew that Lycanroc had a point, but it hurt him to realize that reality. "They are 'a little heavy.' You're right Lycanroc. They're obese, but why should that drive us to leave?"
         "Because what's happening to them will happen to us more slowly. It already is! Just look at yourself and me. We're both fatter than we ought to be." "Right," countered Manectric, "but why can't we just control ourselves better and lose the weight? I mean, if we will become like the other two, why hasn't it happened yet?"
         "I don't know," Lycanroc admitted, "but I think that we are less food motivated and eager to please than the other two are. And I know you say that you can control yourself, but the fact remains that in practice--and I've seen this happen too many times to count--you won't be able to restrain yourself. If you want some evidence, I heard Gregory on the phone with Dave the other day, saying that…" he paused, obviously trying to contain and check tears, "They put Salamence down because he was too fat to move without assistance that Dave and Nancy were incapable of giving. You may remember that he promised to stick to a diet. That obviously didn't happen."
         Manectric's knees buckled, and he collapsed at the news. Salamence had been so strong-willed, so determined. How had this happened? "Those…those bastards," was all Manectric could choke through his sob. Lycanroc came over to comfort him, "Now do you understand? These people are nefarious and dangerous. We have to leave."
         "No," Manectric stormed, "that's not the solution either. The solution is to lose weight. I can convince the others and hold them to account, I swear!" Lycanroc nodded, but replied, "Your valor is notable, but you can't. Just go ask Mightyena to go run around with you when he's not eating or sleeping, or Arcanine. I'll bet you they won't because I've asked them and have been rebuffed on numerous occasions."
         "Fine," declared Manectric, " I will. And I will succeed; just watch."

         Manectric found Arcanine and Mightyena relaxing and chatting in the shade of the verandah. It was a pleasant autumn day, about 70 degrees Fahrenheit, not too humid, and breezy. Despite all these things, the two were sitting in the shade contentedly. "Hey, Manectric," called Mightyena with a laugh, but not bothering to get up. "So what are you guys doing," asked Manectric innocently. To which Arcanine lazily responded, "Not much. And you?"
         Then Manectric got to the critical question, "So, Lycanroc and I were thinking about having a tag team battle between the four of us." Mightyena's face lit up at the suggestion, "Yes, please," he said, beginning to breath more quickly with excitement; Arcanine grimaced, but having heard Mightyena's response, and not wantingg to be a buzzkill plastered on a fake grin and replied wearily, "Why not? I'm in."
14331122111112.title: Enter the grind of daily life.

143311221111121.content:
"Are you allright, Arcanine?" Manectric whispered as the two walked toward the battlefield, with Mightyena jogging, or slogging, as Arcanine had snidely put it, ahead. "I'm ok, I just don't much feel like a battle at the moment. Man, he'll tire hinself out before the battle at this rate," Arcanine replied, marking his final remark with a gesture toward Mighyena. "He may well, but I'm happy to see his enthusiasm that he hasn't seemed to have for much but food these past few weeks," Manectric pointed out, subtlely hinting to Arcanine that something was wrong. But Arcanine merely shrugged, "If you say so."
         "I do say so," insisted Manectric, letting the slightest touch of irritation show. "I wonder why," Arcanine wondered, seeming to genuinely question. Manectric softened his tone, "Look, Arcanine, Lycanroc and I have a theory. And it concerns you too. You've also seemed sluggish these past few weeks. You've been reluctant to play or do anything but eat, sleep, or talk. Lycanroc and I are worried about you."
         Arcanine scoffed, "Come on, you must have guessed that we've been bored and unable to do much else but eat, sleep, and talk, as you say." Manectric let more irritation back into his voice, "Arcanine, Lycanroc and I think that you and Mightyena are dangerously overweight. Look, Salamence…Salamence is dead because he was too fat to walk by himself, so the humans had no choice but to surrender him to euthanasia."
         "At least he died with some dignity and less pain," Arcanine reasoned. "That doesn't erase that he is dead!" Manectric bellowed, with more ferocity than he had meant, "And dying with 'dignity,' if you insist on calling it that, is a screwed up notion humans invented for killing any undesirable humans and Pokemon. Do you think that such a thing is good? They killed him! They killed him!" Manectric raged, "You insufferable moron! Look at yourself! You have troubled even standing, and I can hear your labored breathing from here. And, look, Mightyena needs to take a break from the jog he just took to Lycanroc! You're pathetic! He's pathetic! And you'll end up like Salamence if you don't change!"
         "So I see that this is the purpose of the battle. If you win, you'll want me to diet and lose weight. But if we win, you'll leave us alone and not bother us about our weights again. Deal?" Manectric nodded, "that was the deal I was going to propose to you. Do you accept? Mightyena will be your partner." Arcanine nodded, with his tongue lolled out the side of his mouth, panting from the short walk that wouldn't have tired him at a run when Manectric had met him.
         Manectric and Arcanine walked over to where Lycanroc stood and Mightyena lay. "Did you propose the deal?" Lycanroc asked Manectric. "Yes," Arcanine butted in, "And I accept." "Good," panted Mightyena, struggling to his feet, "because I did too." When Mightyena had gotten to his feet, the two teams separated and Lycanroc called out, "we're giving you two a couple of minutes to prepare a battle strategy and tactics. Use them well."
         Arcanine and Mightyena nodded. "So what do you want to do?" Manectric quietly asked Lycanroc, "Mightyena and Arcanine have some powerful moves between them, and I have no doubt that the two will team up on me." Lycanroc nodded, "No, I expect so. I'll deal with Arcanine, and could you deal with Mightyena?" When Manectric nodded, Lycanroc continued, "Great, thanks. Remeber, tire them, make them run at us. Use moves like Thunderbolt that have great range and accuracy. Stay to the side of Mightyena. The stadium is big enough to allow for that. Run as fast as you can, and hope he doesn't hit you. Then just launch attacks. But try staying out of range at first and see how that works out. I'll use Dig and get behind Arcanine. Let's see how that works."
         When Manectric and Lycanroc looked up, they saw the other two Pokemon staring impatiently. "What's taken you so long?" called Mightyena. "I assume you two are ready then?" rejoined Manectric. "Ok," called Lycanroc, "is everyone ready? 3…2…1…Begin!" And with that, Lycanroc dove into the ground. Mightyena and Arcanine looked at each other and smiled. Arcanine launched a Flamethrower and Mightyena a Shadow Ball. The Flamethrower was pathetically short, and the Shadow Ball was easily dodgeable. Manectric then countered with a Shock Wave that hit Mightyena dead on. Mightyena howled in pain and got up to move closer; and Arcanine, frustrated at the pathetic range of his attack, also forced himself to his feet to moobe closer. Manectric released another Shock Wave, again aimed at Mightyena, who this time shot a Dark Pulse and countered effectively, knocking Mightyena flat on his back. Arcanine then used the Extremespeed attack to get close to Manectric to launch a Flamethrower when Lycanroc jumped up and delivered a Rock Slide, too late to save Manectric but soon enough to bury Arcanine. Both Arcanine and Manectric limped off the battlefield, no longer able to continue the battle.
         "Good battle," chuckled Arcanine, "but I'm sure Mightyena can win." Manectric laughed, "Look at him, you doofus, he's exhausted from my attack and from walking across the stadium and launching a few attacks." Arcanine swatted at Manectric playfully, "Maybe, but Mightyena knows far more powerful attack against an evenly matched opponent than Lycanroc." "Lycanroc knows Earthquake and Rock Slide. Don't lecture me on powerful moves," Manectric countered jovially, happy to have his friend back.
         "Don't lecture me on exhaustion. Look, Lycanroc's out of breath from one attack," Arcanine sniffed. "Look, Arcanine," Manectric argued, realizing the gravity to which the conversation was turning, "Lycanroc and I need to go on a diet too, and we all agreed to lose weight to get to a more proper weight, but we thought that we should all diet together." "But us especially," Arcanine supplied for Manectric. "No," Manectric countered, "I mean, we would all hold each other to account, yes, but it's not just you and Mightyena."
         Manectric turned in time to see Lycanroc get slammed with a Dark Pulse. But Manectric could see one of Mightyena's hind legs wobbling spastically. Manectric was just thinking about how funny the leg's collapse would be when the leg buckled and folded, collapsing Mightyena in a heap, seeming to knock the breath out of Mightyena.
         Seeing this weakness, Lycanroc ran to Mightyena rear and used Earthquake, knocking Mightyena out.
143311221111121.title: To the battle.

1433112211111211.content:
"I…demand a rematch," Mightyena panted while he slowly rose to his feet. "Nope," declared Lycanroc, "neither you nor anyone but me is fit to battle right now. So, no, just no."
         "But, Lycanroc," Mightyena complained. "Shut up, you stupid tub-of-lard. There will not be another battle today between us. Do you understand?" Mightyena's face contorted and triaged among sadness, anger, and hurt. Lycanroc paused and tried to calm himself before he managed to fight back another outburst, "I'm sorry, Mightyena; I shouldn't have said that. You aren't stupid--fat, tremendously fat, and obstinate--but not stupid. Listen, I don't want to seriously hurt you; and you know that if you continue, you will get hurt, right?"
         Mightyena shook his head, "So you say. Look, you won't get me to agree to the terms of your agreement if you won't fight me again. Arcanine, are you with me?" Arcanine flinched, hating to decide between his friends whom he would support, "Look, I think that both of your plans have good cases and merits. You two are too emotionally charged right now to see it though."
         Manectric barked a demeaning round of laughter and scoffed at Arcanine's blatant refusal to take sides, "Arcanine doesn't have values; does he?" Arcanine whirled around, "Damn you, Manectric. I don't need hectoring. I'm confused, ok? You're right, I don't have a value judgment on this issue. I don't know whom to side with. But you mock me and laugh at my confusion. Explain, damn it; don't mock me! You know what? No, I won't take part in your little diet because you have attacked me." Mightyena smiled with relief, apparently pleased with the result of Arcanine's decision.
         "Damn it," Lycanroc seethed at Manectric. "You had to speak. You had to get your damned two cents in, didn't you? Now you've probably damaged our friendship irreparably. Way to go, you blundering dunce." "Lycanroc, I know that saying sorry won't get me very far," Manectric started.
         "Do better then," Lycanroc snapped in retort. "But," Manectric continued, "I think that I can smooth our relationship over with the other two. We just need to lose weight ourselves and show how competent we are in battle."
         Lycanroc shook his head, "Manectric, you really are a great obtuse dunce sometimes and so intelligent at others. You really don't understand that no evidence will convince the other two, do you?" Manectric shook his head, "I'm not talking about against them, I'm talking about at the upcoming party that Master Gregory is having in a couple of weeks. If we show far better resutls there than the other two, maybe they'll come around to our side."
         Again Lycanroc shook his head, "Again, you're being naïve. Those two won't accept any evidence that contradicts their position."
         "Well," countered Manectric, "it's worth a shot for us." Lycanroc agreed enthusiastically.

         The exercising part of the weight-loss regimen was the easy part, but not one that contributed to substantially fewer calories on a day-to-day basis. The diet, which was the substantially more important part of reducing their caloric intake, proved the far more difficult part. Manectric would occasionally catch Lycanroc snacking, Lycanroc would have to remind Manectric not to take leftovers from Gus, the chef.
         Lycanroc shed his excess weight easily, having been merely a few pounds over his ideal weight limit, according to himself; but Manectric found the weight loss more challenging. Manectric was about ten or fifteen pounds over his ideal limit, Lycanroc, who had been a mere five pounds overweight, estimated. But Manectric could feel a couple of pounds melting off himself in the couple of weeks he had been at the diet. He was now somewhere between five and ten pounds overweight, according to his partner's estimates and losing weight quickly.
         Manectric felt a pang of regret when he noticed Mightyena walk into the room. Lycanroc had been right; the two's relationship had cooled considerably. Mightyena, who had once spoken in warm, bubbly tones to Manectric and Lycanroc noe spoke in more subdued and terse ways. Replies were shorter, more curt than they had once been. Arcanine had done much the same thing to the two on a diet. Mightyena and Arcanine had never been unfriendly, Manectric had commented to Lycanroc.
         "Right," retorted Lycanroc quietly, "but they were never this subdued toward us before." Manectric sighed; he knew Lycanroc was right--he seldom wasn't--but the realism was nevertheless discouraging.
          "Good morning, bubblebutt," Manectric greeted playfully. "Good morning, Manectric," Mightyena replied tartly, as if he were lost in a train of thought, before he plodded slowly, not cautiously or deliberately, but slowly, as if hampered by some sort of baggage over to his food bowl where he flopped noisily and began eating. "Look, Mightyena," who pretended not to notice. "Mightyena," Manectric hissed. Mightyena turned, stared angrily for a moment before he went back to stuffing his face with the food in front of himself.
         "Look, Mightyena, we need to practice tag team battlling. I overheard Master Gregory say that out tournament is going to be double-battles at the next tournament." Mightyena turned balefully before he sighed, "Look, we'll be fine. You're panicking too much. We don't really need to do much. Can I at least eat in peace?"
         Manectric looked down at the Pokemon lying spread eagle on the floor with an abdomen that looked like a pear and that was slowly heaving itself up now. "Ok, that's fine, it was just a suggestion."

1521111.content:
Pinwheel Forest in the Unova Region is filled with many friendly Pokemon who happily greeted people who passed through. Of course they don't wait by the paved road for someone to come, but anyone who went off the main path, deciding to take the scenic route, would be welcomed by the local Pokemon. However, this only applies to the west side of Pinwheel Forest; due to how much darker the east side of Pinwheel Forest is, introverted Pokemon are the ones who make it their home, such as Maria the Snivy.

Maria was not fond of socializing; she enjoys nothing more than the quiet that comes with being alone. Although she does have friends, it is because they have a mutual liking for tranquility, so they mostly spend their time together sharing blissful silence. But Maria doesn't tell her friends about the best places she found to get some peace. Whenever no one is watching, Maria sneaks off to somewhere deep in the forest where she can relax by herself. If other Pokemon knew, there would be more of a risk that someone would spot them going there, find it, and promptly blab about it to everyone, ruining it for Maria.

Though one day, when Maria was searching for a place to unwind like she usually does, she came across a waterhole. Maria was surprised she hadn't discovered it sooner; Maria thought she had already seen everything in the forest by that point. Curious, she dipped her foot into the water. For some reason, the water felt like an otherworldly type of amazing on her skin. She soon began submerging her entire body in the water, except for her head. Since Maria is the only one who knows about the waterhole, she is able rest in silence. Unbeknownst to Maria though, her body was slowly growing thicker while in the water, but she was too busy enjoying the peace and quiet to notice.

Eventually the sun began to set, so Maria was best off going home; you never know what kinds of Pokemon might be lurking around during the night. Maria attempted to get up, but found it oddly difficult. At first she thought that she just underestimated how much the water clinging to her body weighed, but she glanced her eyes downwards at the water and saw in the reflection that her own face had somehow plumped up significantly. Maria sat there in shock, soon realizing the reason behind her difficulty moving. She tried desperately to lift her now much heavier body out of the water, wanting to see if the rest of her body had actually gotten fatter as well.

After she finally managed to get out of the water, Maria looked over her now large body. Snivys are typically 18 lbs., but Maria had to have been at least 50 lbs. now. Her originally slender body was now covered in rolls of fat, her belly now sticking out several inches in front her. Her limbs were practically flat like real leaves before, but now, they were like lumpy tubes. This would certainly surprise anyone who knew Maria, but she didn't care about that since she was alone most of the time. All she cared about is if she herself was fine with being fat. info.brief_description: An Interactive, with stories centered around expanding Pokemon.
info.description:
Note: Please do not add 'choice/option' chapters if you are not going to write proper story content right after that. It's false development. Thank you.

Since the previous story, "Pokemon Weight Gain/Inflation" by Ender simply evaporated along with the deletion of his account, I've decided to revive it.

For those who are possibly confused with the ongoing story: http://www.writing.com/main/interact/item_id/1952094-Pokemon-Weight-GainInflatio...
You can send a message to me to clarify things that I possibly left out. Other than that enjoy the crazy scale of the story. Thanks!

Some guidelines down here:
- Pokemon from all regions, types and sizes may be involved in this story, at the writer's leisure!
- This is a Pokemon-based story, so while human beings are allowed, try to keep expansion of them to a bare minimum.
- Try to keep chapters and plot development PG-rated.
- That means no explicit things like sex, violent/gory descriptions etc. If they are implied however, that's fine.
- Keep within the themes of Weight Gain and Inflation. (No pregnancy allowed, please.) You may mix them up as you wish.
- It does not matter how fast or how the Pokemon expand, as long as it is described and justified.
- Vore is acceptable, as well as digestion, but don't be too graphic about it.

Other than that, enjoy your stay!
